protocol_name: The Association between VEGF Gene Polymorphisms and Stroke: an updated systematic review and meta-analysis
protocol_name_html: The Association between VEGF Gene Polymorphisms and Stroke: an updated systematic review and meta-analysis

status_info: We are still developing and optimizing this protocol

components.data: Methods：A systematic literature search of PubMed, Embase, Wed of Science, The Cochrane Library, Elsevier, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, China Biology Medicine disc, WanFang Data, VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals, Sciencepaper Online were conducted by two study investigators independently. The latest data for searching articles was November 1st, 2017. Key words used in the research were: “VEGF” or “vascular endothelial growth factor” or “vasculotropin”, “single nucleotide polymorphism” or “SNP” or “polymorphism” or “mutation” or “genetics” or “variant”, and “stroke” or “cerebral infarction” or “cerebrovascular disorders”.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Methods：A systematic literature search of PubMed, Embase, Wed of Science, The Cochrane Library, Elsevier, China National Knowledge Infrastructure, China Biology Medicine disc, WanFang Data, VIP Database for Chinese Technical Periodicals, Sciencepaper Online were conducted by two study investigators independently. The latest data for searching articles was November 1st, 2017. Key words used in the research were: “VEGF” or “vascular endothelial growth factor” or “vasculotropin”, “single nucleotide polymorphism” or “SNP” or “polymorphism” or “mutation” or “genetics” or “variant”, and “stroke” or “cerebral infarction” or “cerebrovascular disorders”.

components.data: Inclusion and exclusion criteria： Studies eligible for inclusion in this meta-analysis needed to meet the following criteria: (1) independently published case-control studies focused on associations between VEGF polymorphism and risk of stroke; (2) these studies provided genotype or allelic distributions; (3) genotype or allelic distributions in the control group was in accordance with the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (HWE). The exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis were: (1) animal studies; (2) there were a large difference in the general data of the subjects, such as age, gender, and there may be a significant bias in the literature. When individual authors published several articles from the same patient population, only the most recent or complete articles were taken into account in the analysis.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Inclusion and exclusion criteria： Studies eligible for inclusion in this meta-analysis needed to meet the following criteria: (1) independently published case-control studies focused on associations between VEGF polymorphism and risk of stroke; (2) these studies provided genotype or allelic distributions; (3) genotype or allelic distributions in the control group was in accordance with the Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (HWE). The exclusion criteria for the meta-analysis were: (1) animal studies; (2) there were a large difference in the general data of the subjects, such as age, gender, and there may be a significant bias in the literature. When individual authors published several articles from the same patient population, only the most recent or complete articles were taken into account in the analysis.

components.data: Data extraction： All qualified information was drawn from all the eligible publications. The following data were collected from each study: the first author's name, the date of publication, country, ethnicity, sample size, the genotyping method.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Data extraction： All qualified information was drawn from all the eligible publications. The following data were collected from each study: the first author's name, the date of publication, country, ethnicity, sample size, the genotyping method.

components.data: Quality score assessment： We used the Newcastle Ottawa scale (NOS) to assess the quality of these case–control studies. The NOS ranges from zero to nine stars, and more than a score of 7 was taken to be of high quality. Two authors independently evaluated the quality of the included studies and resolved all the differences through discussion.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Quality score assessment： We used the Newcastle Ottawa scale (NOS) to assess the quality of these case–control studies. The NOS ranges from zero to nine stars, and more than a score of 7 was taken to be of high quality. Two authors independently evaluated the quality of the included studies and resolved all the differences through discussion.

components.data: Evaluation of statistic association： All the statistical analysis was conducted by Review manager 5.3program. We performed the association between +936C/T, -2578C/A, and -1154G/A polymorphisms and the risk of stroke by calculating OR and 95% CI. The association was estimated with the use of the allelic contrast, the dominant model, the recessive model, and the homozygous contrast. When the P value was >0.1 and I2<50%, the pooling data was performed by fixed-effects model, or, the random-effects were applied. Heterogeneity assumption was assessed by Cochran’s χ2 based Q-statistic test and I2 test. The pooled OR was counted by the method of Mantel–Haenszel, with 95% CI calculated by Woolf’s method. The potential publication bias was valued by Begg’s funnel plot and Egger’s test. HWE of the genotype distribution of controls was assessed by Pearson’s χ2 test.
components.name: Section

source_data.section: Evaluation of statistic association： All the statistical analysis was conducted by Review manager 5.3program. The association was estimated with the use of the allelic contrast, the dominant model, the recessive model, and the homozygous contrast. When the P value was >0.1 and I2<50%, the pooling data was performed by fixed-effects model, or, the random-effects were applied. Heterogeneity assumption was assessed by Cochran’s χ2 based Q-statistic test and I2 test. The pooled OR was counted by the method of Mantel–Haenszel, with 95% CI calculated by Woolf’s method. The potential publication bias was valued by Begg’s funnel plot and Egger’s test. HWE of the genotype distribution of controls was assessed by Pearson’s χ2 test.
